repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - High Efficiency Lighting Pilot
            Trust Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the project as
            marginally satisfactory, similarly, the institutional
            development impact is rated modest, and, as for
            sustainability, the rating is considered uncertain, given
            the negligible project design, and implementation which did
            not address the issue of sustainability. It is considered
            that the project succeeded in demonstrating the technical
            feasibility of reducing emissions of greenhouse gases, and
            simultaneously reducing local contamination, through
            widespread installation of high efficiency lighting,
            however, the project failed to demonstrate the financial
            feasibility of such endeavor, contributing only modestly,
            towards building the institutional capacity for
            technological change, energy conservation, and demand-side
            management at the implementing utility. Among the many
            lessons, it is suggested that: 1) replicability, and
            sustainability are essential elements in demonstration
            projects, and deserve close consideration, and, be
            explicitly incorporated in the project design, strategy, and
            activities; 2) the well planned implementation scheme -
            based on decentralized units, and independent trust funds -
            was successful, giving the implementing agency an overall
            project control; and, 3) bulk procurement can be an
            important leverage.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - High Efficiency Lighting Pilot
            Trust Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. The borrower, Comision Federal de Electricidad
            (CFE) was highly effective, with a strong commitment from
            the executing agency, which exceeded in some instances, the
            targets of the project. However, a disappointing result was
            the demand coincidence factor, overestimated by the
            consultant, and not detected during supervision. It is
            important to mention that Mexico was selected as a pilot for
            testing verification of carbon savings, and a technical
            audit will validate project results in terms of greenhouse
            gas emissions. The key lessons learned suggest that: 1) the
            establishment of independent trust funds was a key factor
            for successful sales and coverage goals, showing to be
            efficient, expeditious and inexpensive; 2) the choice for
            fluorescent bulbs (FLs) with high technical specifications
            and reliability favored consumer acceptance. Furthermore,
            from an overall marketing/ sales point of view, the price
            subsidy was an asset. 3) an adequate tariff policy should be
            in place, providing in turn, incentives to low income
            consumers; and, 4) decentralization of Implementing Units
            was paramount in achieving sales and distribution goals.

repnme.cdata!: Mexico - High Efficiency Lighting Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The High Efficiency Lighting Pilot
            Porject is a result of and a contribution to Mexico's
            commitment to environmental protection. The objectives of
            the project are to: a) demonstrate the technical and
            financial feasibility of reducing emissions of green house
            gases and simultaneously reduce local environmental
            contamination through the widespread installation of high
            efficiency lighting; b) build the institutional capacity for
            technological change and energy conservation; c) provide a
            replicable model for demand-side management (DSM) in Mexico
            and elsewhere in the developing world; and d) strengthen the
            Federal Electricity Commission's capacity to practice
            DSM on a sustainable basis. The project will replace
            approximately 1.7 million incandescent bulbs with
            fluorescent light bulbs (FLs) in the cities of Guadalajara
            and Monterrey. The project includes: 1) the acquisition of
            FLs; 2) the purchase of vehicles, metering equipment,
            personal computers, office equipment and sales stands; 3)
            consultant services for canvassing, marketing, testing,
            auditing and project evaluation; 4) the cost of engineering,
            monitoring and evaluation, billing and accounting; and 5)
            the direct costs of implementing the project. The project
            will result in substantial economic benefits including: 1) a
            comparable or higher lighting level at reduced cost; and 2)
            annual energy savings and postponement of costly investment.
